text:
I'm really excited and honored
to be presenting today.

My past and present work
on multi-material design for miniature robots.

But before I start talking
about the miniature robots, I would like to give you
what actually inspired

me to build these
miniature robots and how I, basically,
build up on that philosophy

of small scale animals. So first, one of
those animals is ant

So ants is very
abundant in the nature. And they can do incredible
stuff collectively.

So they can build bridges. They can build towers,
even float like a boat,

and also teach each other. For example, a more
experienced ant

can teach a less experienced
ant how to find food, for example, for foraging.

But little known about-- so it's a lot known about
their collective behaviors.

But they are not only
collective superorganisms. They can also have--
they also possess

incredible individual
mechanisms, for example,

have you seen a flying ant? This is not actually a reverse
video of an ant falling down.

Have you seen it
jumping ant navigating

through cluttered
forest environments? So this incredible creature
is called trap-jaw ant.

They developed over the
evolutionary process an incredible mechanism for
coping with environment,

as well as escaping predators. So they use this miniature
mechanism, the jaw.

And use it for
multi-functional purpose. So they just not
only catch the prey,

but they can also flip and
then jump to escape predators.

But, also, they could
use their legs, not only for crawling, but also
using it for jumping

in a cluttered environment. So this robot could
inspire us to build

more capable miniature robots. And these robots could
be deployed in mass.

And then they could
start working together. They could navigate very
cluttered, very difficult

environment. They could communicate
towards a common task. So even if some of
them would fail,

it wouldn't hinder them
to accomplish the task. So it's really low-cost
mass producible systems.

But, obviously,
building these robots is challenging in terms
of miniaturization,

for example, embedding
multi-functionality to their mechanical design, but
also manufacturing them in mass.

Let's look at the robot
design across scales. So when we look at on my
left side on the macroscale,

we could achieve
an amazing progress in developing robots
that could be stationary,

that could be on wheels, that
could be flying around thanks to the advancement in
electromechanical actuation

systems and modern
manufacturing processes. When we look at the
microscale and these robots

were inspired by
micro-organisms, researchers have
developed various methods

for actuation and
navigating, for example, bloodstream in human
body or other organisms.

For example, one
day, these robots could deliver some medicine
to certain part of the body.

Notably, these robots
have not self-contained actuation mechanisms.

Everything is outside. So it's external
actuation or excitation. It could be electromagnetic.

It could be heat or
a laser pointing.

And their mass manufacturing is
thanks to the microfabrication process. So they could be really
mass produced in batches,

like the silicon chip. When it comes to the
mesoscale, again, we

would face a challenge
of miniaturization, for example, miniaturizing the
conventional electric motors is

difficult. And also, for
example, manufacturing

multiple components into
a single small package would have another trade-off.

So that would actually increase
the complexity of the design, as well as the
size of the robot.

And we would like to scale
these robotic swarms. So we need to figure out
how we can fabricate them

in batches, just like
the micro robots. And I call this
problem a 3M problem.

And throughout my PhD
and here at Stanford, I'm trying to address,
scratch the surface

of how I can address
these 3M problem.

Let's look at how
robots were built and look at the
state of the art.

So for swarm
robotics, we can see that these robots could
be mass produced thanks

to their simple
mechanical designs. But they have profound
communication capabilities.

And, obviously,
these robots were built to study complex
swarm behaviors.

But they were limited
to 2D surfaces. So it could be a benefit
to actually include

more capabilities or
embed more capabilities that these robots could
go to the 3D space.

When it comes to the terrestrial
multi-locomotion robots-- so they are not only
bound to the 2D surface,

but they can now
achieve 3D locomotion--

we can see that they
have complex designs. So they use conventional methods
of transmission, actuation,

and other mechanisms. For example, it could
have a crawling--

so they have separate
mechanism for locomotion. So you can have a
crawling mechanism,

which is separate from
the jumping mechanism. And this would be hindering
their miniaturization, as well

as mass manufacturing. Just imagine yourself
putting together all of these small
three-dimensional components

in a meticulous manner. And then try to scale
it up to a larger

swarm or collective behavior. So if you look at the
conventional methods,

we can see that there is
certainly some challenges. So if you like to, for
example, design a simple joint,

so we would have
two kinematic pairs. So that would be pin and socket. That would be moving
relative to each other.

But if we would
like to motorize, it we would include
a motor on the joint. Then further, if you would
like to have a high torque

actuation of the
link or the joint, we would introduce some gears,
gearboxes to the motors.

And then if you would
like to, for example, generate variable
power actuators,

we would include a spring,
which we could load it. And then generate
variable power actuation.

But, also, if you
would like to have, for example, this
continuous power actuation, we would like to
generate a sudden power

output from the mechanism,
we would be loading a spring, charging it, storing
the potential energy,

for example. So we can see that the
complexity actually increases when we include more
functionality to the design.

And also, number of
components increases. So it could be that it's
higher cost, more manufacturing

and assembly time. But imagine you have a
so-called smart material or just

a cantilever beam, let's
say, here in this example. Imagine that under no
stimuli, it could be flexible.

So it could act
as a rotary joint. Then you would
apply some stimuli.

And this joint now
starts to move. It would have its
embedded functionality.

In order to generate
high torque, you would just increase
the size of the--

or the thickness
of the cantilever, or you could play with the
geometry of the system. And then-- sorry,
and then you could

vary the stimuli to have
the variable power output or variable torque
output of the system.

And you could also play
with the bistable nature of these structures. So you could build a structure
that could be bistable.

And you could flip or
change between two states. Also, just imagine, now,
you can have multiple layers

of it built on
top of each other, just like a printed
circuit board. Then you could embed each
functionality in a layer

so that you don't
have to assemble three-dimensional components. So that's how we
built the tripod.

It's a multi-locomotion
Millie robot that can generate jumping,
crawling, and walking.

And these robots are
inspired by trap-jaw ants. The mechanism in the
middle, actually,

is very similar to what trap-jaw
ants have in their jaws. So it can open up its legs
to 100 or about 180 degrees,

and snap through,
and close it quickly. The robot weighs about 10 grams.

And it can fit on your palm. And maybe half of the weight
in the surface of the robot

is actually taken
up by the batteries.

So let's see how it works.  We can do vertical jumps
on any three of the edges,

as well as we can-- by changing the actuation
sequence of these shape memory

alloy actuators that I'm
going to mention later, we can actually jump forward.

We can also vary the power
to get variable output

from the locomotion
mechanism, as well as we can overcome
obstacles, for example,

or even detect stairs. So we can embed sensors on
board of these PCB body.

And, of course, we could also
do some athletic behaviors.

So why is it important
to embed multi-locomotion for these small scale animals?

It's because, if you look
at the small scale animals, as long as they shrink,
everything around them

environment becomes
bigger and bigger. So they have to cope
with these environment. And, for example,
they could crawl

across a flat smooth surface. But then when they
have an obstacle, they could jump
over the obstacle.

So that's what we
would like to show here is that we can
transition from crawling

to flic-flac or rolling
locomotion and as well as jump over the obstacles.

And making this simple and
cheap robots is really,

I think, beneficial if you
could mass produce them. And that could have
very simple, let's say.

electronics as well as
sensing capabilities. But then with
increasing the number,

we could basically
create tasks for each. And then they could
work together instead

of like creating a one
sophisticated robot, perhaps. And then here, for
example, we show that

the leader-follower scenario,
where a leader robot here continues to scan
the environment.

So the follower doesn't
scan it so it doesn't spend too much energy on that. And the leader would just let
the follower know that there

is an obstacle coming. And then would
jump over this gap.

And follow here would be
computing how many steps it should crawl before it can
come to the edge of this gap

and then jump over it.  There is a lot of
possibilities we

could do with simple
and low cost and mass manufacturable robots. We could distribute the tasks.

But this is how it's made. So it's very similar to what
how your iPhone or your Samsung

device is manufactured. It's a layer by layer
manufacturing process. But, unlike, these electronic
components, devices,

we embed mechanical
functionality into the into the multi-layer process. So you can see here that we
have the PCBs, some adhesive

and the captain, for
example, for the joints. And then we also embed shape
memory alloy actuators that I'm

going to discuss later. And by sandwiching all
of these components into so-called Quasi 2D
structure or sandwich,

we can fold this
sandwich to obtain the three-dimensional
shape of the object. So, basically, addressing
not only the structure,

but also the functionality. You could embed
multiple materials for different functionalities.

And we studied the
performance of the robot. So we could--

I showed you that we
could change the stimuli. So that he'll
obtain, for example,

to generate different heights
of jumping or the distance

or we also studied the
robot's locomotion performance on sloped or flat terrain.

So when we look at
the cost of transport, so it's like energetic
cost of transport,

is a measure of how much
energy is required for a robot to travel a certain distance.

especially distance jumps. We can see that on
the on the left. We see that there is
terrestrial locomotion insects

like the trapdoor and jumping
spider and desert locust. And we compare it
that with Tribot

and other
multi-locomotion robots. The Tribot could actually
be have a comparable cost

of transport, for
example, close to desert locust or the jumping spider. But, obviously, the trap-jaw
ants here beats everyone.

Obviously, this data is for
that particular time frame. But there are also
robots now, who

could actually generate really
high power at very small scale.

And here is the
evolution of the robot. So we started with
the origin, where

we started like 3D
printing methods, as well as composite methods. And then we embedded
some sensors

to control the step size. The crawling step size, as
well as the jumping height of the robot.

Then we really embedded
all that knowledge into self-contained robot.

And later, we also study
the cage, for example, you notice that if the
robot would fall on its edge

on one of the sides,
it wouldn't be able to continue its
operation, because it's

just flat on the on the side. So this kind cage helps
it to self-right, and then

continue its motion.  Later before I left EPFL,
I was involved in work,

where we were thinking about
really, can we start from 2D? And then it would self-fold and
then self-right itself into 3D.

And then it would
continue its operation. So this 2D assembly
process helps us

to maybe sandwich
multiple of them. And then deploy. And this flat robots could
self-assemble and then

start moving without
storing it in 3D.

So the robotic origami allows us
to embed a lot of functionality
and mechanisms. So here, we show-- this is the Tribot cage.

Here, we could also embed
all of the components like the self-righting
mechanism in 2D process.

So you can be really
creative about how you can generate these
three-dimensional

functionalities in 2D, and then
manufacture everything in 2D, and obtain that at the end.

But we could also have
this cage foldable. So you could fold it,
deploy, it would self right,

absorbing some shock and
then continue its operation.

I touched on the fabrication
process from the 2D components to the 3D structure
of the robot.

But what we really
do in design space is we actually
define a 3D robot.

And all its necessary component. And then we,
basically, unfold it.

We unfold it to the 2D sandwich. And then decompose it
to multiple layers.

And that's how the
design process works. We try to generalize or provide
a more systematic methods

for this approach. So as I mentioned, there is
a very important function

of the origami, is the
geometry, as well as the mechanisms that you would
like to embed in the structure.

And materials here is playing
a very important role. So we put these three components
concurrently rather than

sequentially,
because, for example, the shape of a smart actuator
that can bend, for example,

it plays a big role. For example, its geometry would
be very much related to it,

because I will show
you in a minute, how the modeling or the
behavior of these actuators

are actually related
to this geometry, also, thermo mechanical components.

And all of that together
generate these mechanisms. So it's a fusion of
the three components.

That's why we put it in
the concurrent process rather than like a
sequential process.

or injection molded plastics,
or CNC machined aluminum,

for example. And that one is already defined
by your manufacturing processes. They might come at the end of
the design process, for example.

But here, we also pay
attention to the fabrication

processes based on
these three components. And this process is really
not definitive at the end.

So we have to do some
characterization, mechanical and material
characterization,

at the end of the sandwich or
the composed each component. And we have to refine this
design process so that we
could reach desired result.

So at the end, I think like a
concept or more like a paradigm,

we could, one day,
perhaps, build this-- make these methodologies
into design tools.

So we could really design. We have eagle for
PCB design or KiCad.

And we could manufacture them
with embedded manufacturing

processes, as well as test them,
and then customize those designs

according to those tests.  So that was for the design
of these versatile robots.

And I would like to talk
about what actuation methods or actuators that actually
made these robots possible

to move and generate
the functionality. There are four types of
actuators that I was studying.

So one of them is a linear
coil and a bending sheet

and linear wave. So these three actuators were
shape memory alloy or nickel titanium alloy, which you
could, basically, form them

into, let's say, a coil. And then anneal it or hit
it at high temperatures.

And that alloy would
memorize that shape. So once you stretch it,
and then you apply a heat,

or you pass a
current through it, which is called joule heating,
that would be compressing, again, to the memorized shape.

So you can do this cyclic
extension and compression

of the actuator to be used
for robots, for example, like an artificial muscle.

So how we actually use this
shape memory alloy actuators? The coil in this case.

So, for example, if you like
to have this crawling motion, we just need a smooth
continuous operation.

So it's like going
back and forth. So for that, we
needed three coils.

And then we could activate one
at the bottom to close the leg.

And then activate the ones
on the side to open the leg. So we can, basically, control
it continuously smoothly.

But in order to generate this
sudden snap through mechanism,

we could still use the
same approach here. So we can open the legs of the
robot to 180 or more degrees.

And then we could start
activating the bottom one. So that activation creates
actually a compression

at the middle joint. So at some point,
the mechanism is

looking for a stability point. So it snaps through
to the other direction generating a high torque.

And that torque is
translated to ground reaction force that lifts the robot up.

It's worth mentioning here
is that you can see here

that this shape memory alloy
spring behavior is quite similar to the steel spring, for
example, which behaves according

to Hooke's law. But one difference here is
that the shear modulus here

is a function of temperature. So because it's a thermally
activated actuator,

the temperature will define how
stiff this spring would behave.

And then we embedded some
sensors on the on board. And we used this actuator.

And then here, I show here
is that we can, basically,

modify the power. We could modulate
the input power to generate different
jumping heights.

And these springs are actually
very tedious to manufacture.

You have to call them up, and
also go through that process. So in order to avoid
that we were thinking,

can we actually have
a layer of the sheet and use it for that purpose?

But that would be a
bending rather than like a linear
compression motion.

But the challenge, let's
say, with this bending sheet type of actuator is
that you wouldn't

be able to hit it the coil. It has a higher
electrical resistance.

So in order to reduce that,
we implement another layer of heater, which would
not directly hit it,

but conduct the heat
to the actuator. Again, it's very similar
to bending sheet equations.

So where the elastic
modulus is now as a function of the temperature
and the temperature could be--

and that elastic
modulus temperature is a function of called
martensitic fraction

coefficient. I will not go to the
details of the equations. But, basically, their
behavior could be non-linear.

Let's say, it could be
cosine or sine function. It could be exponential. So different literature
put it in a different

and tried it in
different methods. In here, we can clearly see that
our behavior for the actuator

is quite a cosine
or sine function. And we embedded these
actuators for, let's say,

a flat sheet of material
that could self fold. And then not only self fold, it
could be controlled, and also

transition to other states. This one is going from flat
to u-shape, from u shape

to, let's say,
tetrahedral shape.

So I mentioned about
the coils, which are difficult to manufacture. And, maybe, a sheet would
be easier to manufacture.

But the sheet cannot
store potential energy. So we would need,
certainly, something

that could be coil-like,
could store energy, more elastic unlike sheet.

So we combine both
properties in a flat sheet type of wave SMA actuator.

So the fabrication
process is very easy. So you could have a
sheet of material.

And then you could score this
serpentine structure on top onto the nitinol sheet.

Cut out using the laser. And then not only
you could create these stretchable elements,
but you could also stack them.

So you could create high
force actuators, as well by just using adhesive
and other methods.

And we use these
actuators for the case

of reconfigurable grippers. So what does it do? So the reconfigurable
gripper is a suction gripper.

And as you know, the suction
gripper in the industry have fixed shapes. So the amount of-- or the shape
of the objects they can pick up

are really, really
limited to their shape. But we are thinking,
can we actually have

reconfigurable version or shape
morphing version of this robot? So we, again, used
origami design methods.

So you can see here in the mode
one, it has a larger aperture. And then it could change
its aperture accordingly

by selectively activating
embedded shape memory alloy actuators. And the manufacturing
process is very simple here.

That we have some
silicone, where we're integrating more rigid
components like fiber glass.

And then we embed actuators. So it becomes a single
piece of material.

And then here, please note
that in the inside of them, we use coil, steel
coil type of actuators.

But the actuators
from the outside are wave type of actuators. As you can see here, is
that, for example, picking up

a very narrow and long
object, like the pen here is quite difficult. So we can
switch to a different mode.

And if you like to represent
so many different geometries

of these apertures, and then
the objects that you want to pick up, you can really
play with origami structures,

and then how these structures
could generate those shapes.

And this actuator
that I want to present is quite different from
the shape memory alloys.
But it has benefits. So this is based on fluidics. So it's pneumatic.

One of the challenges of the
shape memory alloy actuators is their speed or the bandwidth.

They're quite slow. But pneumatics, we know,
that it can be quite fast.

And we were thinking, can
we design different types of robots, but could also
be behaving or reconfiguring

to different shapes really fast? And that's how we
come up with the idea of embedded fluidic chambers.

So what it does is you could
embed fluidic channels, for example, in these
miura origami pattern.

You can see there is
mountain and valley folds. And then you can
design those folds

to have some fluidic chambers. If you suck the air out from
these chambers, some of them

would be collapsing. And this collapse would
generate some folds. So that's the basic
idea of the structure.

So you can see here, by
having a single port, you can distribute all of that
actuation onto a 2D surface.

And you can design it to
be mountain or valley. You could also design
it to be having

different moment or torque
generated at their folds.

What we also noticed that
by changing, for example,

by altering the
fluidic chamber, so the cross-section area
of the fluidic channels,

you could also have certain
delay in certain actuation response.

So we use that delay,
actually, to generate sequential folding behavior
with these structures.

That pretty much summarize that
multi-layer, multi-material

processes really could
speed up and enable us to have mass producible,
multi-functional robot.

And next, I would
like to, actually, touch on the next application,
which I'm actually involved here

at Stanford. It was very exciting for me
to see different challenges

in different robotic
fields, where this approach could be applied.

So as you know,
haptic interfaces

could enable us to interact
with the digital environment. It could be a virtual
world, a metaverse,

or any other definition
of the system. So in this three-dimensional
virtual world,

we would like to have
compelling, realistic, intuitive

interaction behaviors. So in order to be touching
something, for example, when

you interact with
the physical world, for example, touching this
bottle, when you pick it up,

you, basically, would feel
what's the weight of the object. For example, there are
multiple sensors in your body,

one of them is
mechanoreceptors that tell you how heavy is this object.

And one of them is
like, for example, you would feel the friction. Another thing, for example, does
the bottle rotate in your hand?

You could also feel it
by rotational friction. Or you could also feel
how soft is the bottle.

So all of that
multi-modal information is processed in your
brain, but picked up

by the mechanoreceptors. So these mechanical
receptors provide information on different attributes
of the object.
It could be texture. It could be rigidity. It could be weight and so on.

And the haptic devices that
were developed for these cases

is mostly, for example,
for a fingertip, which is the most sensitive
area of our hand for touch.

And these fingertip devices
could generate different degrees

of freedom of motion. So degrees of freedom,
basically, you could imagine that it is
like, how complex attributes

of the object we could recreate,
or how complex it could be the interaction behavior.

So, for example, if you
go from left to right, you see that the three
degrees of freedom--

we have the three degrees
of freedom of haptic devices that were inspired by
conventional pointer

or parallel robot systems in the
industry and then, basically,

trying to miniaturize them
into a small footprint. But we also see that
we have four degrees of freedom using some origami.

But using, again, some
conventional actuation methods. So really for me, was, again,
coming back to the 3M problem.

Can we, actually, address
it using the same methods that I was presenting earlier?

And that's how I started
working on the fingerprint. So fingerprint is a fully
3D printed haptic device.

So it requires zero
assembly process. And embeds four degrees
of freedom capability.

So it can stretch your skin. It can provide
pressure or vibrations.

And it's really monolithic. So you can design
it in one piece. Print it in one piece.

And then by cleaning
post-processing of this 3D printed piece,
you could have it ready

for your application. So how it works? You have a single piece of
material with embedded actuators

readily in the system,
some fluidic channels. And also the
mechanism is, again,

using some origami that I'm
going to show you later. So this factor interacts
with your fingertip,

giving you four degrees
of freedom interaction and stimulation.

You can change the
frequency of the stimuli so that you can have,
for example, vibration.

You could also have
faster interaction. Our interaction is not
really the same bandwidth.

So we have a varying
frequencies, when we interact. So it could be, for
example, for finer objects

that you want to know
the texture about. It could be higher frequencies
or more coarse objects would

have lower
frequencies, and so on.

So the main thing in the
body of the fingerprint

is this origami mechanism
or waterbomb base mechanism.

It has of eight
foldable actuators. And this foldable actuators
are, basically, again,

like a chamber,
but now 3D printed. And by applying some
vacuum to these chambers,

and selectively through
these fluidic channels, we can make this tactor in
the middle move in the desired

direction. And here is the
origami mechanism. It's a waterbomb base.

This mechanism can generate
three degrees of freedom. So for example, if you
change the angle of the folds

here on the creases, you can
generate different motion on the tactor.

But since our device
is pretty soft, when we actuate all of
these folds together,

it compresses and
generates the pressure. And that's how we
achieved the four degrees of freedom,
which is not defined

by this origami mechanism.  It's really easy to mass
produce a [? skelet ?]

in a single printing process. And some of the
key considerations, obviously, is to think about how
you would design the support,

where would you like
to install them? Because this is a soft material. And we are using very thin
layers for, for example,

the actuator walls. So we would like to have a right
amount of, let's say, support.

But also, we would want to
be able to remove them later after the post-processing so
that it's not very laborious

procedure. And I think key
takeaways from here

is really that we could
change the vacuum pressure to, actually, control the force
output of this tactor.

For example, here, we can
see that the tactor can move and generate different
forces, for example,

for the pressure z-force, by
just changing the input fluidic

pressure. So it gives us
another dimension, where we could do maybe
a closed loop control.

And I further extended this
method to a wrist worn device. So unlike wrist-- like
the fingertip device,

wrist worn device allows
you to place more components

or generate
display-like capability on the wrist, because there is
so much real estate on the wrist

rather than on the fingertip. So this device can
generate about 20 newtons

of force, which is quite high. And, again, here, we use a
little slightly different

method. So we use bellow type
of actuators that can compress when you apply vacuum.

And by selectively
activating these bellows, the tactor in the middle here
can generate different motions.

And I can show you
this motion here.  So the tactor here
generates by playing--

by activating these actuators
in different manner, this tactor can be, for
example, applying shear

in x direction and y. Or it could even apply
like a twist motion

or stretch your skin
or as well as squeeze. So by scaling up this number
of hoxels, for, example,

on your skin, you could
generate a display-like haptic

interaction.  So we are currently
studying this fingerprint

on the phalange, for
example, which is called the haptic relocation. One of the challenges with
having it on the fingertip

is really the physical
interaction between fingers when you're trying to grasp
small virtual objects.

For example, in order to-- we are currently
using these devices

to be relocated as
a ring, for example. And use that to understand
how people perceive,

or how effective it is on the
on the phalange, for example.

these modular displays
